detailed_results.applicability_reasoning: This regulation does not apply to the provided pension scheme rules document for several reasons: 1) The document is a set of rules governing an executive pension life cover scheme and does not contain any sales or marketing content or procedures. 2) The document focuses on defining the legal and operational framework of the pension scheme, including definitions, benefits, trustee duties, and administrative procedures. 3) While Section 6 provides contact information for AIB life, this is purely for service purposes and not for sales/marketing activities. 4) The regulation specifically addresses how regulated entities should handle consumer instructions regarding sales and marketing visits/calls, which is not within the scope of this scheme rules document. The document is a legal/administrative document that establishes and governs a pension scheme rather than a sales or marketing document.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Policies and procedures to be in writing and accessible to employees
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025
detailed_results.applicability_reasoning: This regulation does not apply to this document for several reasons: 1) The document is a scheme rules document that outlines the terms and operation of a pension life cover scheme - it is not itself a policy or procedure document that staff need to reference to perform their duties. 2) The document is meant for trustees, employers and scheme members rather than being an internal procedural document for employees of the regulated entity (AIB Life). 3) While AIB Life is mentioned as the life office and registered administrator, this document does not contain their internal policies and procedures that would fall under the scope of regulation 120 which specifically requires policies/procedures to be accessible to employees. This is instead a customer-facing document that establishes the legal framework and rules of the pension scheme itself. The regulation in question specifically pertains to internal policies and procedures that employees need access to for performing their duties, not scheme documentation provided to customers.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Receipt to be provided
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025
detailed_results.applicability_reasoning: This regulation does not apply to the provided Pension Life Cover Scheme Rules document for several reasons: 1) The document is a set of scheme rules that governs how a pension life cover scheme operates - it does not deal with direct consumer payments or receipts. 2) The document indicates this is an employer-sponsored scheme where 'The employer will pay all premiums under any policy' (Section 2.3), not the consumer/member directly. 3) The scheme is structured as a trust arrangement with trustees managing the scheme, not as a direct consumer financial product requiring receipts. 4) The document focuses on defining benefits, trustee duties, and scheme operations rather than payment processing or consumer transactions. While AIB Life is mentioned as the life office provider, the regulation about providing receipts for direct consumer payments does not apply to this type of pension scheme structure where premiums are paid by employers.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Confirmation of power of attorney to be obtained where relevant
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025
detailed_results.applicability_reasoning: This regulation does not apply to the pension life cover scheme rules document for several reasons: 1) The document is focused on establishing rules for a company pension life cover scheme and does not contain any provisions or procedures related to powers of attorney. 2) While the document discusses trustees, beneficiaries, and administrative powers, it does not address scenarios where someone might act on behalf of a consumer through a power of attorney. 3) The document's scope is specifically limited to defining scheme rules, trustee duties, and benefit provisions for company pensions in the event of death before retirement age. 4) The only parties mentioned in terms of authority are the trustees, employers, and administrators - there is no mention of power of attorney arrangements or procedures for handling them. 5) The document's administrative sections (particularly Section 4 on Trustee Duties and Powers) do not include any requirements for handling power of attorney situations.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Proposed transferee or merging entity to conduct due diligence and verify continuity of service
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025
detailed_results.applicability_reasoning: This regulation specifically addresses requirements for regulated entities that are proposing to be transferees or merge with other regulated entities. The document in question is a pension life cover scheme rules document that outlines the operation of a company pension scheme. While the document does mention AIB life as the life office and registered administrator, it does not contain any content related to proposed transfers or mergers between regulated entities. The document focuses on defining scheme rules, benefits, trustee duties, and wind-up procedures for a specific pension product. There are no provisions or discussions about mergers, acquisitions, or transfers of regulated activities between entities that would trigger the requirements under Regulation 126 regarding due diligence and service continuity in merger/transfer scenarios.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Information to be provided and obtained prior to opening joint account for consumers 8 [81]
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025
detailed_results.applicability_reasoning: This regulation specifically governs the opening and operation of joint accounts between two or more consumers. The document in question is a Pension Life Cover Scheme Rules document that outlines the rules and operation of an executive pension life cover scheme. The scheme described is an individual occupational pension scheme that provides death benefits for a single member's dependants - it is explicitly stated in Section 2.2 that 'The scheme is established for that one person only and that one person will always be the only member.' There are no joint account features or operations described in this document. The document deals with trust-based pension arrangements between an employer, trustee, and single member, which is fundamentally different from the joint consumer accounts that Regulation 127 is designed to govern.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Interpretation (Part 4)
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025
detailed_results.applicability_reasoning: This regulation (307) specifically deals with the interpretation of terms related to consumer insurance contracts, personal injury claims, and direct settlement methods. The document in question is a pension life cover scheme rules document that outlines the operation of an occupational pension scheme providing death benefits. The document is not a consumer insurance contract - it is an occupational pension scheme document governed by the Pensions Act 1990 and Taxes Consolidation Act 1997. The document explicitly states it is an 'occupational pension scheme' established for company pensions, with the employer as trustee and AIB Life as the registered administrator. The terms being defined in Regulation 307 (Act of 2019, method of direct settlement, Personal Injuries Resolution Board) have no relevance to the administration or operation of this type of pension scheme. Additionally, the document's legal framework is clearly established under pension legislation rather than consumer protection or insurance contract law.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Setting subsequent renewal prices
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025
detailed_results.applicability_reasoning: This regulation does not apply to the provided document for several key reasons: 1) The regulation specifically addresses insurance renewal pricing, while the document is about a pension life cover scheme that provides death benefits through an occupational pension scheme. 2) The document outlines scheme rules for company pensions and does not contain any provisions about renewal pricing or consumer insurance policies. 3) The scheme described is an occupational pension arrangement between an employer and trustees, not a direct consumer insurance product. 4) The premium structure described in section 2.3 states that 'The employer will pay all premiums' and that the premium is generally fixed unless specific changes are made - this is fundamentally different from the consumer insurance renewal pricing that the regulation aims to govern. 5) The document describes a B2B product (employer to trustee) rather than a B2C insurance product that would fall under consumer protection regulations.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Closed books
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025
detailed_results.applicability_reasoning: This regulation (316) specifically deals with 'closed books' for insurance policies, particularly home and motor insurance products. The document in question is a pension life cover scheme rules document that outlines the rules and operation of an occupational pension scheme providing death benefits. The key reasons this regulation does not apply are: 1) The document describes a pension product, not a home or motor insurance product which are the specific focus of the regulation, 2) The document outlines a new scheme rules document (version 1 from 2023) rather than a closed book product, 3) The product is administered by AIB life as a pension trustee product under the Pensions Act and TCA regulations, not as a general insurance product. The document falls under pension regulations rather than insurance product regulations regarding closed books.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Insurance intermediaries' involvement in setting price
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025
detailed_results.applicability_reasoning: This regulation does not apply to the provided document for several key reasons: 1) The document is a pension life cover scheme rules document that outlines the structure and operation of a pension death benefit scheme, not an insurance intermediary pricing document. 2) While AIB Life is mentioned as the life office provider, the document focuses on trustee duties, scheme benefits, and administrative procedures rather than pricing or renewal pricing mechanisms. 3) The document makes no mention of insurance intermediary involvement in price setting or renewal pricing - it only discusses fixed premiums paid by employers (Section 2.3 states 'The premium is a fixed amount unless an indexation or annual increase option applies to the policy'). 4) The scheme described is a single-member occupational pension scheme providing death benefits, which is fundamentally different from the type of insurance policy renewals that Regulation 317 is designed to govern.

detailed_results.regulation_title: Responsibility of insurance undertaking or insurance intermediary where more than one insurance undertaking or insurance intermediary is involved in setting the subsequent renewal price
detailed_results.source_name: CENTRAL BANK (SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT) ACT 2013 (SECTION 48) (CONSUMER PROTECTION) REGULATIONS 2025
detailed_results.applicability_reasoning: This regulation does not apply to this document for several key reasons: 1) The regulation specifically deals with setting renewal prices where multiple insurance undertakings/intermediaries are involved. The document in question is a pension life cover scheme rules document that outlines the structure and operation of an occupational pension scheme, not a general insurance product with renewal pricing. 2) The document shows this is a single-provider product offered by AIB Life, not a multi-provider insurance arrangement. 3) The scheme rules document focuses on death benefits and trustee responsibilities, with no mention of renewal pricing mechanisms or multiple insurance providers being involved in price setting. 4) The document explicitly states it is regulated under the Pensions Act 1990 and Taxes Consolidation Act 1997, not general insurance regulations. The pricing and premium aspects mentioned in the document (Section 2.3) are fixed amounts determined solely by AIB Life, not involving multiple insurance undertakings.

detailed_results.applicability_reasoning: This regulation does not apply to the provided pension life cover scheme rules document for several key reasons: 1) The regulation specifically addresses home insurance and motor insurance policies and their related additional financial services at renewal, while this document outlines rules for an executive pension life cover scheme. 2) The document describes a standalone pension product rather than an additional financial service attached to home/motor insurance. 3) The scheme rules document focuses on providing death benefits for dependants before retirement age through an occupational pension scheme structure, which falls under different regulatory frameworks (primarily the Pensions Act and TCA). 4) The pricing and renewal mechanisms described in the document are fundamentally different from those addressed in the regulation, being based on fixed premiums unless indexation applies, rather than the consumer pricing protections for insurance renewals that the regulation addresses. 5) The document shows this is regulated by the Pensions Authority and Revenue Commissioners rather than falling under the scope of this specific CPC regulation.

detailed_results.applicability_reasoning: This regulation (418) specifically deals with the revocation of previous regulations related to licensed moneylenders and insurance requirements. The document in question is a pension life cover scheme rules document that outlines the operation of an occupational pension scheme. The document is governed by different regulatory frameworks, specifically: 1) The Pensions Act 1990, 2) The Taxes Consolidation Act 1997, and 3) Revenue Commissioner requirements. The document makes no reference to consumer lending or general insurance matters that would fall under the scope of the revoked regulations mentioned in Section 418. Additionally, as this is an occupational pension scheme document primarily dealing with employer-trustee relationships and death benefits, it falls outside the scope of the consumer protection regulations being revoked. The document is instead regulated by pension-specific legislation and tax law.
